pullRequest.body:
Joint work with @IsaacHernando and Coleton Kotch.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: I haven't looked at the PR in detail (I will do so tomorrow), but after a quick glance there seems to be some very-near duplication with the file ` Limits/Constructions/Filtered.lean`. @adamtopaz, are you aware of this file?

> I haven't looked at the PR in detail (I will do so tomorrow), but after a quick glance there seems to be some very-near duplication with the file ` Limits/Constructions/Filtered.lean`. @adamtopaz, are you aware of this file?

@TwoFX we looked at the file you mentioned. Indeed, the construction we give in `finsetBiproductDiagram` is essentially the same as `liftToFinset` from the file you mentioned. But there is a key difference: we use biproducts whereas that file uses coproducts. The two are of course isomorphic, but it's more convenient for us to use biproducts as in later constructions we need to consider them as limits. We could have used `liftToFinset` instead, but then we would have had additional work managing the isomorphism with products when we want to prove left exactness. Because of this, I don't think it would save any work to use `liftToFinset`.

### PR summary [67cf6086af](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6504/commits/67cf6086af49de24859c306719e649e890e9035b)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Category.Grp.AB5`|1|
| `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Abelian.GrothendieckAxioms`|521|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ AB4`
`+ AB4Star`
`+ AB5`
`+ AB5Star`
`+ HasCofilteredLimits`
`+ HasFilteredColimits`
`+ colimPreservesColimits`
`+ instance : AB5 (AddCommGrp.{u})`
`+ instance : HasFilteredColimits (AddCommGrp.{u})`
`+ limPreservesLimits`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Can you relate this to exact sequences in abelian categories? Right now, the file `Algebra.Category.Grp.AB5`Â contains a proof that `AddCommGrp` satisfies AB5 in the sense of filtered colimits preserving finite limits, and in the sense of preserving short exact sequences (phrased as `PreservesHomology`). These are of course equivalent in all abelian categories. How much work would it be to prove this equivalence?

> How much work would it be to prove this equivalence?

I think `CategoryTheory.Functor.exact_tfae` is the equivalence you're looking for. :smiley:

> > How much work would it be to prove this equivalence?
> 
> I think `CategoryTheory.Functor.exact_tfae` is the equivalence you're looking for. ðŸ˜ƒ

Nice! Shouldn't the file about `AddCommGrp`Â apply this use this equivalence then rather than giving two separate proofs of equivalent statements?

> Nice! Shouldn't the file about `AddCommGrp` apply this use this equivalence then rather than giving two separate proofs of equivalent statements?

It doesn't really give two separate proofs: It first constructs `colim.PreservesHomology` and then derives the instance `colim.PreservesFiniteLimits` by a single call of `Functor.preservesFiniteLimitsOfPreservesHomology`.
Sorry, I misread!

How about I delete the implication from AB5 to AB4 for now and do the construction from filtered limits and finite products to arbitrary products in another PR? The latter is a change mostly to `CategoryTheory.Limits.Filtered` anyway

As you want, I think it would make sense to have three PRs total, the first defining the AB4 and AB5 axioms (adding AB4* and AB5* should be an easy dualization as well), the second (independent of the first) writing a coproduct as a filtered colimit (and preferably also the dual statement), and the third, depending on both the first and second, which proves that AB5 implies AB4.

You should open new PRs for the first and second, and eventually merge them into this one, making it the third.

I see now that @TwoFX's comment about duplication from last year is essentially the same as my comment. I think the solution is to generalize the `liftToFinset`Â stuff to general cocones/cofans instead of duplicating to apply to biproducts (the generalised API should apply to both situations)
Should I call the duals `CoAB4` and `CoAB5`? :thinking:

I now made this PR only contain the definitions for AB4, AB5, and their duals and I'm working on a second one that contains the following
* Turn `liftToFinset` into a functor `(Discrete Î± â¥¤ C) â¥¤ Finset (Discrete Î±) â¥¤ C`
* Use `preservesLimitsOfEvaluation` (or a modified version of it for finite limits) to prove that it preservers finite limits. (The proof obligation is that for each finite `J`, we need to show that the coproduct over `J` preserves finite limits, maybe that's already available somewhere.

Then I can add to a third PR or here the implication AB5 -> AB4 which should be just a few lines plus the proof that
`colim â‰… liftToFinset â‹™ colim` (is this where you think we need to generalize `liftToFinset` to arbitrary cofans, @dagurtomas ?)

What I had in mind was pretty vague, and for the iso you mention I don't think you need to generalize to arbitrary cofans. 

Using the approach you describe, you just need to prove that finite coproducts preserve finite limits whenever the category has finite biproducts, which is already a better approach than what was initially done in this PR.

I'll review this now and look forward to seeing the other PRs!
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by dagurtomas.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10832927435/job/30058457427)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10832927435/job/30058457035)
bors r+
In `GroupCat/Abelian.lean` there is a proof that `AddCommGroup` is AB5. Would you mind putting the instance for your new class there?
bors r+

Can this be written as
```suggestion
  obj S := â¨ X
```
like the ` âˆ X` below?
It's not the same, since we're restricting here to a finite subset of alpha.
Oh my bad thanks!

```suggestion
instance [HasCoproducts C] [HasFilteredColimits C] [HasFiniteLimits C] [AB5 C] : AB4 C where
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
      coproductIsoColimitFinsetBiproductDiagram (F.obj âŸ¨Â·âŸ©)) <| by
```

```suggestion
  preserves {S} hS :=
    { lift := fun E => biproduct.lift fun âŸ¨a,haâŸ© =>
        let K' := K â‹™ (evaluation _ _).obj âŸ¨aâŸ©
        let S' : Cone K' := Functor.mapCone _ S
        let hS' : IsLimit S' := isLimitOfPreserves _ hS
        hS'.lift âŸ¨_, fun j => E.Ï€.app _ â‰«
          biproduct.Ï€ (fun a : A => (K.obj j).obj âŸ¨aâŸ©) âŸ¨a, haâŸ©,
            by intro i j f; simp [â† E.w f]âŸ©
      fac := by
        intro E j
        dsimp
        ext âŸ¨a, haâŸ©
        let K' := K â‹™ (evaluation _ _).obj âŸ¨aâŸ©
        let S' : Cone K' := Functor.mapCone _ S
        let hS' : IsLimit S' := isLimitOfPreserves _ hS
        simp only [biproduct.lift_map, biproduct.lift_Ï€]
        apply hS'.fac
      uniq := by
        intro E m hm
        dsimp
        ext âŸ¨a,haâŸ©
        let K' := K â‹™ (evaluation _ _).obj âŸ¨aâŸ©
        let S' : Cone K' := Functor.mapCone _ S
        let hS' : IsLimit S' := isLimitOfPreserves _ hS
        simp only [biproduct.lift_Ï€]
        apply hS'.hom_ext
        intro j
        rw [hS'.fac]
        simp [hS'.fac, â† (hm j)] }
```

```suggestion
  preservesFiniteLimits _ _ _ := âŸ¨@fun _ => inferInstanceâŸ©
```

```suggestion
import Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Adjunction.Limits
import Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Filtered
import Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.FunctorCategory
import Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Preserves.Finite
import Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.Shapes.Biproducts
```
What is the purpose of this example? Removing it allows you to remove the import `Adjunction.Limits`Â and the `noshake`.
Ah, I guess @adamtopaz put it in for teaching purposes, will remove it.

Up until this point, everything could be done for coproducts instead of biproducts. I imagine that it would be useful to write an arbitrary coproduct as a filtered colimit its finite "sub-coproducts" (and the dual for products). This would need to be done for general cofans rather than the arbitrary chosen coproduct `âˆ`. Could you try this alternate approach and see if it works?
Sounds like a good idea, I'll give it a try.
Add `AB4*`Â and `AB5*`.
This should be changed to a TODO for now.

```suggestion
For `AB4` and `AB5`, we only require left exactness as right exactness is automatic.
```

```suggestion
open Limits

```
I think `Classical` is unnecessary, right?

```suggestion
/-- A category `C` which has products is said to have `CoAB4` (in literature `AB4*`)
provided that products are exact. -/
```
Maybe `AB4star`Â to conform better with the literature? I don't have strong opinions on this.
`AB4Star` maybe? They did the same thing with C*-algebras, so I'll conform with that.

```suggestion
attribute [instance] AB4.preservesFiniteLimits
```

similarly for all the instances below.
Should this be `extends HasCoproducts C`?
I'm always unsure. I guess it depends on whether instances will rather have a `HasCoproducts` instance that's already defined prior to a `AB4` instance?
I'm also unsure, you should ask on zulip
This seems to have been resolved on zulip, let's keep it like this!
Could you add references (e.g. to the Stacks project) because these phrasings of the definitions are not exactly the same as in the original Grothendieck Tohoku article.

@adamtopaz Did you have any specific references? [The stacks site](https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/079A) is phrased in a way that presupposes the category to be Abelian, which we, for good reason, don't...
I wasn't following any references. I suppose that in lieu of references you could explain in the module docstring how the definitions here relate to those in Tohoku and/or the stacks project.
Are the few sentences sufficient, @joelriou?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory/Abelian): AB4 and AB5 axioms
